The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) announced today a partnership with the African Development Bank on the South Sudan Climate Resilient Food Security and Agricultural Transformation Project (CRAFT). This landmark initiative aims to bolster agricultural productivity, enhance food security, and foster economic resilience in South Sudan through innovative climate adaptation strategies.

July 02: GCA Partners with World Bank to Enhance Water Security and Sanitation in Senegal

The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) announced today its collaboration with the World Bank on the Integrated Water Security and Sanitation Program for Senegal (PISEA). The landmark project, with an initial financing of $200 million from the World Bank, aims to improve water security and sanitation services for over seven million people in Senegal, including 600,000 residents of greater Dakar.

June 28: GCA and Palli Karma-Sahayak Foundation sign Memorandum of Understanding to increase resilience of vulnerable communities in Bangladesh

R otterdam, the Netherlands and Dhaka, Bangladesh, 28 June 2024 - The Palli Karma-Sahayak Foundation (PKSF) and the Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) today signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) aimed at enhancing climate resilience and poverty reduction efforts in Bangladesh. This agreement marks a significant step towards bolstering the capacity of PKSF to address the challenges posed by climate change.

September 17: Global Center on Adaptation: Turning Waste into Wealth through Climate Adaptation

The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) marked a significant milestone in climate adaptation, sustainable urban development, and green jobs with the inauguration of 12 Black Soldier Fly (BSF) units in Mukuru, Nairobi today. The initiative, undertaken through the Africa Adaptation Acceleration Program (AAAP) in partnership with the African Development Bank (AfDB), DanChurchAid, and local partners Akiba Mashinani Trust (AMT) and Miramar Foundation, is set to revolutionize waste management in one of Nairobi's largest informal settlements while providing employment opportunities for young people by equipping them with skills in sustainable agriculture, waste management, and business management.

Source: Company Website

September 16: Africa Partners Delivering Adaptation Results: $10 Billion of Development Investments Made Climate Resilient

Highlighting the results of the first 36 months of the world's largest climate adaptation program, the Africa Adaptation Acceleration Program (AAAP), ministers, experts and practitioners in and outside of Africa, gathered for the program's 4th Partnership Forum in Nairobi, Kenya. AAAP so far mainstreamed climate adaptation into over $10 billion of development investments in Africa from various international financial institutions (IFIs), benefiting over 63 million people across 37 African countries. Source: Company Website

July 11: GCA welcomes GROHE Team Ocean Rowing 850 kilometers for Water Awareness to Floating Office Rotterdam

The Global Center on Adaptation (GCA) welcomed the GROHE Team Ocean to GCA's Floating Office in Rotterdam's Rijnhaven today. This event was the culmination of the team's 850 kilometer journey rowing on the Rhine River over 10 days from Basel, Switzerland to Rotterdam, the Netherlands.

The GROHE Team Ocean, composed of adventurers Wilco van Rooijen, Bela Evers, Sara Eenhoorn, and Joost Schutte, embarked on this challenging rowing expedition to draw attention to increasing water scarcity and the necessity of behavioural change.

title: Updated: July 16, 2025: UC Santa Cruz partners with UC Davis to launch new Central Coast medical program and other recent news
bodyText:
UC Santa Cruz and UC Davis are partnering to launch a new program that will train future physicians deeply committed to the health and well-being of Central Coast communities and increase access to care.

Senator John Laird (D-Santa Cruz) was responsible for including $1.5 million in the state budget for the two campuses to establish the UC Programs in Medical Education Central Coast (PRIME Central Coast). July 14: University Of California Santa Cruz: Here's how we help an iconic California fish survive the gauntlet of today's highly modified waterways

Imagine a world where just six out of every 100 newborns make it to their teenage years, the rest unable to survive post-apocalyptic environmental conditions that have become too strange and dangerous for human life. That's the plight of California's once-thriving Chinook salmon, a population that now sees 94% of its juveniles die within the few weeks they spend trying to reach the sea from the freshwater sources where they first hatched.

This tragic reality is almost entirely due to how their native waterways in the state's Central Valley have been turned into a system of levees, channels, and large high-head dams that are tightly managed almost exclusively for human needs. In terms of how water is allocated, wildlife is essentially an afterthought. Source: Company Website

July 07: University Of California Santa Cruz: Art, activism, and ecosexuality converge in Beth Stephens' new film, Playing with Fire

The film reimagines fire not as a threat but as a powerful element deserving of connection, care, and sensual engagement-challenging traditional environmental narratives.

Set against the backdrop of California wildfires and climate change, the documentary features interviews with firefighters, scientists, artists, and Indigenous leaders, as well as performances by students and faculty.

Beth Stephens, professor of art at UC Santa Cruz and a pioneering voice in the ecosexual movement, celebrated the world premiere of her latest feature film, Playing with Fire: An Ecosexual Emergency.

Co-directed with longtime creative partner Annie Sprinkle, Playing with Fire is a bold, visually rich documentary that fuses environmental advocacy, queer sexuality, and performance art into what the duo describes as "a love poem to fire that engages art, activism and offers advice for navigating our current times." The film debuted June 20 in San Francisco at the Roxie Theater as part of Frameline 49, the longest-running and largest LGBTQ+ film festival in the world.

By making gene editing more precise and accessible, CRISPRware supports the development of personalized gene therapies like those already helping people with genetic diseases.

A Ph.D. student in biomolecular engineering at the University of California, Santa Cruz, has built a software program designed to facilitate the kind of precision genome editing involved in the development of cutting-edge therapeutics for genetic conditions such as certain metabolic or blood disorders, like sickle-cell anemia.

July 02: University Of California Santa Cruz: Eric Palkovacs appointed new director of Institute of Marine Sciences

As a researcher, Palkovacs explores connections between evolutionary and ecological processes in freshwater and coastal ecosystems, with the goal of informing biodiversity conservation and sustainable fisheries management. He currently also serves as UC Santa Cruz's associate vice chancellor for research, and as director of the Fisheries Collaborative Program.

July 01: University Of California Santa Cruz: Games promote preparedness and build community resilience to wildfire

If a wildfire causes an evacuation, people are forced to leave quickly and make decisions under pressure about what to bring and what to leave behind. These challenging decisions can have serious impacts on the outcome of a fire, and are what players confront in 'Firewise Residents,' one of three simulation games created by University of California, Santa Cruz computational media researchers to build preparedness for a wildfire scenario.

title: Updated: July 24, 2025: University Of California Santa Cruz: New research shows how immigration status can become a death sentence during public health crisis and other recent news
bodyText:
In the United States, immigration status has long created hierarchies within our society, where some can participate fully in public life, while others are excluded. These divisions have serious consequences for our communities, including when it comes to public health. A research project led by the University of California, Santa Cruz recently uncovered a particularly alarming example of this effect by looking back on excess deaths in California throughout the course of the COVID-19 pandemic.

July 14: University Of California Santa Cruz: Here's how we help an iconic California fish survive the gauntlet of today's highly modified waterways

Imagine a world where just six out of every 100 newborns make it to their teenage years, the rest unable to survive post-apocalyptic environmental conditions that have become too strange and dangerous for human life. That's the plight of California's once-thriving Chinook salmon, a population that now sees 94% of its juveniles die within the few weeks they spend trying to reach the sea from the freshwater sources where they first hatched.

This tragic reality is almost entirely due to how their native waterways in the state's Central Valley have been turned into a system of levees, channels, and large high-head dams that are tightly managed almost exclusively for human needs. July 07: University Of California Santa Cruz: Art, activism, and ecosexuality converge in Beth Stephens' new film, Playing with Fire

The film reimagines fire not as a threat but as a powerful element deserving of connection, care, and sensual engagement-challenging traditional environmental narratives.

Set against the backdrop of California wildfires and climate change, the documentary features interviews with firefighters, scientists, artists, and Indigenous leaders, as well as performances by students and faculty.

Beth Stephens, professor of art at UC Santa Cruz and a pioneering voice in the ecosexual movement, celebrated the world premiere of her latest feature film, Playing with Fire: An Ecosexual Emergency.

Co-directed with longtime creative partner Annie Sprinkle, Playing with Fire is a bold, visually rich documentary that fuses environmental advocacy, queer sexuality, and performance art into what the duo describes as "a love poem to fire that engages art, activism and offers advice for navigating our current times." The film debuted June 20 in San Francisco at the Roxie Theater as part of Frameline 49, the longest-running and largest LGBTQ+ film festival in the world.

title: Updated: July 15, 2025: University Of California Santa Cruz: This year's Dickens Universe will explore a neglected Victorian melodrama and other recent news
bodyText:
Charles Dickens's The Old Curiosity Shop became an instant bestseller when it was published in serial form between 1841 and 1842. Queen Victoria was a fan.

Since then, the book's reputation and fervent readership have faded, while perennial favorites like A Christmas Carol, Great Expectations, and Oliver Twist still find large audiences.

The Old Curiosity Shop's neglected status might have something to do with its polarizing reputation. Some Dickens admirers praise its engaging melodrama and explorations of deformity, while others think the book is pure schmaltz.

July 16: UC Santa Cruz partners with UC Davis to launch new Central Coast medical program

UC Santa Cruz and UC Davis are partnering to launch a new program that will train future physicians deeply committed to the health and well-being of Central Coast communities and increase access to care.

Senator John Laird (D-Santa Cruz) was responsible for including $1.5 million in the state budget for the two campuses to establish the UC Programs in Medical Education Central Coast (PRIME Central Coast). The new program, which will complement existing UC PRIME programs across the state, aims to accept applications in early 2026 and enroll its inaugural cohort of students in 2027.

"UC Santa Cruz is deeply committed to meeting the health care needs of the Central Coast, and this is an important step in our efforts," Chancellor Cynthia Larive said. July 14: University Of California Santa Cruz: Here's how we help an iconic California fish survive the gauntlet of today's highly modified waterways

Imagine a world where just six out of every 100 newborns make it to their teenage years, the rest unable to survive post-apocalyptic environmental conditions that have become too strange and dangerous for human life. That's the plight of California's once-thriving Chinook salmon, a population that now sees 94% of its juveniles die within the few weeks they spend trying to reach the sea from the freshwater sources where they first hatched.

This tragic reality is almost entirely due to how their native waterways in the state's Central Valley have been turned into a system of levees, channels, and large high-head dams that are tightly managed almost exclusively for human needs. In terms of how water is allocated, wildlife is essentially an afterthought. Source: Company Website

July 07: University Of California Santa Cruz: Art, activism, and ecosexuality converge in Beth Stephens' new film, Playing with Fire

The film reimagines fire not as a threat but as a powerful element deserving of connection, care, and sensual engagement-challenging traditional environmental narratives.

Set against the backdrop of California wildfires and climate change, the documentary features interviews with firefighters, scientists, artists, and Indigenous leaders, as well as performances by students and faculty.

Beth Stephens, professor of art at UC Santa Cruz and a pioneering voice in the ecosexual movement, celebrated the world premiere of her latest feature film, Playing with Fire: An Ecosexual Emergency.

Co-directed with longtime creative partner Annie Sprinkle, Playing with Fire is a bold, visually rich documentary that fuses environmental advocacy, queer sexuality, and performance art into what the duo describes as "a love poem to fire that engages art, activism and offers advice for navigating our current times." The film debuted June 20 in San Francisco at the Roxie Theater as part of Frameline 49, the longest-running and largest LGBTQ+ film festival in the world.

A Ph.D. student in biomolecular engineering at the University of California, Santa Cruz, has built a software program designed to facilitate the kind of precision genome editing involved in the development of cutting-edge therapeutics for genetic conditions such as certain metabolic or blood disorders, like sickle-cell anemia.

As a researcher, Palkovacs explores connections between evolutionary and ecological processes in freshwater and coastal ecosystems, with the goal of informing biodiversity conservation and sustainable fisheries management. If a wildfire causes an evacuation, people are forced to leave quickly and make decisions under pressure about what to bring and what to leave behind. title: Wild barley genomics mapped for climate resilience, as grain research boosted
bodyText:
Murdoch University announced multiple grain research projects.

An international team of scientists from Australia and China has unveiled the first chromosome-scale genome of a wild barley species, with hopes to boost both sustainability and yield in domestic grain production.

Led by researchers from Murdoch University and the Beijing Academy of Agriculture and Forestry Sciences (BAAFS), the study, published in Nature Plants , identified crucial genetic adaptations, including the duplication of stress-response genes that enable efficient nutrient intake under alkaline stress conditions.

When stimulated to overexpress, the genes doubled in biomass within the plant and offered improved yields, even in harsh conditions.

"Our findings offer transformative potential for Australia's agricultural sector, particularly in regions like Western Australia and South Australia where there is significant dryland soil salinity," Professor Chengdao Li, director of the Western Crop Genetics Alliance said.

"By breeding salinity-resistant grain crops, we can safeguard yields in drought-prone areas, reduce our costly reliance on fertilisers whilst maintaining productivity, and make a tangible step towards Australia's 2030 sustainability targets.

"Additionally, the extraordinary resilience of H. brevisubulatum's genome equips us with genetic tools to future-proof staple crops against climate extremes, ensuring the competitiveness of our grains sector."

Professor Peter Davies Murdoch University's director of the Food Futures Institute said the findings would help place Australian researchers at the forefront of climate-smart crop innovation.

"By accelerating the integration of wild barley's genetic traits into breeding programs, researchers will be able to deliver new varieties within the next decade and offer timely solutions for farmers battling rising temperatures and soil degradation," he said.

The finding comes as two new projects supported by the Grains Research and Development Corporation begin at Murdoch University, investigating new productivity boosts for grain crops.

The projects included developing a novel spray for broadacre cropping, with $8.1 million invested in understanding how biopolymer sprays could reduce evaporation on crops.

Professor Daniel Murphy, director of the CSIRO Murdoch Bioplastic Innovation Hub, said the spray could help prevent soil evaporation, by facilitating rainfall runoff into the furrow and boosting plant water use efficiency.

"The sticky spray would be applied to crops to potentially deliver chemicals, nutrients or antifreeze proteins from bacteria," Prof Murphy said.

Further research into quantifying the value of applying cold plasma to wheat and canola seeds has also begun, with researchers studying the potential improvements in grain yields.

Cold plasma, formed through ionising gas using electric currents can be fed through water, allowing producers to apply the plasma through liquid application. Associate Professor Kirsty Bayliss, from Murdoch University's Harry Butler Institute, said previous testing showed encouraging results in germination rates for plants.

"We will now also be testing plasma-activated water to increase nutrients and manage disease levels," she said.

"Through rigorous economic analysis, it aims to provide a definitive answer as to whether this technology should be implemented by growers. This includes a potential adoption pathway if implementation is economically sound.

Both research projects conclude in 2028, with results and recommendations to be made available to growers.

title: Updated: July 25, 2025: UC Santa Cruz students discover sunflower sea stars keep kelp-hungry urchins at bay and other recent news
bodyText:
In underwater experiments off Alaska, red sea urchins kept their distance from kelp placed near caged sunflower sea stars, suggesting that the mere presence of these predators can protect kelp forests. Kelp forests are under stress, and sea stars may be part of the solution. Once-thriving kelp ecosystems have collapsed in parts of the Pacific following the local extinction of sunflower sea stars in the 2010s, prompting interest in whether reintroducing them could help the kelp recover. Student divers helped lead this real-world science. UC Santa Cruz undergraduates carried out the experiment as part of a hands-on marine ecology course, gaining published credit and firsthand experience addressing an urgent environmental problem.

Sea urchins have no brains or hearts. But put them in the proximity of the unmistakable sunflower sea star, and somewhere in their pin cushion-like body, they sense trouble. That's the main finding in a new scientific study by ecologists and undergraduates at the University of California, Santa Cruz, who wanted to see if this particular type of sea star would deter urchins from eating kelp.

For this study, published on July 9 in the journal Proceedings of the Royal Society B, UC Santa Cruz students who completed the university's highly regarded scientific diving training donned SCUBA gear and placed caged sunflower sea stars (Pycnopodia helianthoides) on the sea floor a few miles east of Sitka, Alaska, where resident urchins have turned once-thriving kelp beds into barrens.

The course, BIOE 159 Marine Ecology Field Quarter, is an immersive and immensely rewarding experience-offering students not only the opportunity to do true aquatic research, but also have their work published and give them a sense of what's possible career-wise. In past years, students in the course have spent the quarter in the Gulf of California in Mexico and Moorea in French Polynesia.

"It's very gratifying to see our work published and presented as maybe another way to protect and restore coastal kelp populations," said the study's lead author, Rae Mancuso. "Kelp forests are highly productive, economically important, and culturally valued ecosystems. But in recent years, throughout the northeastern Pacific, these forests have undergone dramatic declines."

That's the plight of California's once-thriving Chinook salmon, a population that now sees 94% of its juveniles die within the few weeks they spend trying to reach the sea from the freshwater sources where they first hatched.

This tragic reality is almost entirely due to how their native waterways in the state's Central Valley have been turned into a system of levees, channels, and large high-head dams that are tightly managed almost exclusively for human needs. Beth Stephens, professor of art at UC Santa Cruz and a pioneering voice in the ecosexual movement, celebrated the world premiere of her latest feature film, Playing with Fire: An Ecosexual Emergency.

Co-directed with longtime creative partner Annie Sprinkle, Playing with Fire is a bold, visually rich documentary that fuses environmental advocacy, queer sexuality, and performance art into what the duo describes as "a love poem to fire that engages art, activism and offers advice for navigating our current times." title: Fuel-free solar sails could power the next generation of spacecraft
bodyText:
Credit: University of Nottingham.
Space exploration usually brings to mind rockets burning through vast amounts of fuel to escape Earth and journey through the solar system.
But what if spacecraft could travel without carrying fuel at all? A new study from the University of Nottingham suggests that may soon be possible, thanks to a new type of solar sail that uses sunlight in a smarter way.


Solar sails are not a new idea.
For decades, scientists have imagined using large, ultra-thin sheets to catch the momentum of sunlight to propel spacecraft, much like wind pushes a sailboat. Traditional designs rely on reflecting sunlight to generate thrust.
The Nottingham team, however, is developing a new class of sails that don't just reflect light-they bend it.
These "transmissive solar sails" are covered in microscopic refractive patterns that steer and accelerate spacecraft using light alone. Because they don't need engines or fuel, they could enable long-duration space missions, reduce costs, and open the door to more sustainable space exploration.
The research, published in Acta Astronautica, introduces an optimization framework that helps scientists design and test these tiny patterns. By fine-tuning how the patterns bend light, the team achieved far greater efficiency and control than earlier concepts.
Ph.D. student Samuel Thompson, who led much of the technical development, explained how the team modeled the sails. "I developed a ray-tracing simulation to characterize and optimize patterned, refractive solar sails to maximize their acceleration and stability," he said.
Because the light behavior is complex and unpredictable, Thompson also built a reinforcement learning algorithm to test thousands of possible designs and automatically improve them.
This approach means the sails could be customized for specific missions-whether to push a small satellite through low-Earth orbit or to propel a deep-space probe on a long journey. They could even be redesigned mid-development to match changing mission needs.
The Nottingham researchers believe these sails may be especially valuable for sustainable space operations. One promising use is clearing out space debris, since solar sails could move small, uncontrolled objects out of Earth orbit without requiring expensive propulsion systems.
Beyond space exploration, the work may also have planetary applications. The team has contributed to international research exploring the idea of solar sail-enabled "planetary sunshades." These giant sails, positioned in space, could reflect or diffuse sunlight to help cool Earth's climate as part of global geoengineering strategies.
University of Nottingham researcher Dr. Cappelletti recently presented this concept at a United Nations event on climate innovation, highlighting its potential role in future climate resilience.
Meanwhile, the NottSpace research team is already integrating transmissive sails into real-world missions. Their in-house CubeSat projects, WormSail and JamSail, will use these sails for experiments ranging from mapping GPS jamming signals to supporting pharmaceutical research in space.
By reimagining how spacecraft can harness sunlight, Nottingham's transmissive solar sails point to a future where we can travel farther, explore longer, and even help protect our planet-all without using a drop of fuel.

title: Councils seek to reduce climate-change risk
bodyText:
Deadly heatwaves, increased flooding, rising seas and damaged infrastructure are some of the climate-change perils the winner of a current tender covering nine inner-metropolitan councils will need to grapple with.

M9 - an alliance of the Melbourne, Darebin, Hobsons Bay, Maribyrnong, Merri-Bek, Moonee Valley, Port Phillip, Stonnington and Yarra councils - is seeking a consultant to manage a climate-change resilience planning project.

"Damage from climate change is set to impact the billions of dollars worth of assets that local government manage," M9 tender documents say. "Reducing the physical impacts of climate risk is dependent on improved planning and management of assets."

The Resilient Asset Management and Investment Project (RAMI) aims to find ways to address climate resilience challenges while reducing costs. A major objective is to "deliver a tool" that can be embedded into existing council systems and processes and applied to nine high-risk flood sites (one per council) to "build internal capacity using effective change management".

The M9 alliance incorporates some of the highest flood-risk areas in the metropolitan area, including Maribyrnong, where devastating floods in October 2022 hit 572 homes, and 47 villas in the Rivervue retirement village.

The Maribyrnong River has flooded roughly every 10-20 years since 1871, hitting what are now high-density suburbs like Footscray, Yarraville, Moonee Ponds, Maribyrnong, Flemington, Avondale Heights and Aberfeldie.

Rising seas are another danger facing M9 councils. For example, more than 16,000 properties in Melbourne's Southbank are at high risk of damage from sea-level rises and storm surges within 17 years, according to a major report released in 2022. The Victorian Marine and Coastal Council report - which includes research from The University of Melbourne and Climate Risk - warns the total Victorian damage bill could reach

$442 billion by 2100.

The flooding would cause extensive damage to residential and commercial properties as well as transport routes. Port Melbourne and Australia's biggest urban development project at Fishermans Bend are among the M9 areas at risk.

Tom Kompas, University of Melbourne environmental economics professor and lead researcher, said both his team and Climate Risk reached similar conclusions, despite using different models.

He hoped the research would help guide authorities in determining where properties should be built in future.

"If you build a house now in the wrong area you're going to have trouble," he said. "At some point for some communities, retreat is the only option."

Other studies show that rising heat is the greatest problem facing every M9 council. Killer heatwaves are responsible for more deaths each year than all other types of disaster combined, and scientists say that more resilient housing and infrastructure is needed.

The latest projections from scientists at the CSIRO show that temperatures in Melbourne could reach an unprecedented 50 degrees within decades.

title: Farmers get on front foot in evolving war against weeds
bodyText:
Australian grain and cotton growers are proving weeds can be beaten, investing significantly in strategies to help improve their control.

Managing weeds costs the grain and cotton industries an estimated $4.4 billion per year, a report from Australia's national science agency CSIRO has found.

Despite the large expenditure, growers are reaping the rewards. The impact of crop yield has fallen from 2.8 million tonnes in 2016 to 1.2 million tonnes in 2025, which translates into higher production and income.

"Weed control remains one of the biggest annual costs for growers, but the investment is paying off," CSIRO research scientist Rick Llewellyn said.

"By staying ahead of the weed seed bank, resistance and adopting smarter, more targeted practices, growers are protecting long-term profitability and enabling flexibility in their system."

Weed management demands being on the front foot and strategic planning, central west NSW fifth-generation farmer Richie Quigley said.

"We spend a huge amount of time and money combating weeds and there is a lot of strategy behind it to make sure we are using all the tools in the toolbox," he told AAP.

"They are becoming much harder to kill and control and we have to be at the top of our game to be able to manage them."

Growers are combining pre-emergent herbicides, harvest weed seed control, crop rotation and new precision spraying technologies in their management strategy.

Effective weed control was critical in adapting to climate change, CSIRO technical officer Jackie Ouzman said.

"Climate variability does pose significant challenges to growers but they are responding really positively to these challenges," she said.

"Growers are well positioned to cope with more variable climate, with the practices they're currently doing."

The most costly weeds to manage are ryegrass, brome grass, sow thistle, wild radish and wild oats, while the costliest fallow weeds in grain production at a national level are melons, heliotrope and fleabane.

The CSIRO study shows the need for continued investment in weed management research to unlock productivity, climate resilience and sustainable land use.

"The only reason we're not seeing widespread yield losses from weeds today is because of years of sustained research and grower innovation," Dr Llewellyn said.

"This is a quiet success story, but it's a battle where you can't pause."

title: Climate change threats outlined for growing Lake Macquarie communities
bodyText:
The risk of bushfires, floods and lake water rises are expected to grow dramatically in coming decades.

The northwestern corner of Lake Macquarie is expected to see its bushfire risk grow by 130 per cent later this century and experience a 19.7 per cent increase in rainfall and a 0.4-metre rise to the lake water level by 2050, according to local government modelling.

Lake Macquarie City Council is expected to place its draft Teralba to Toronto (T2T) Climate Resilience Plan on exhibition after Tuesday night's Standing Committee Meeting at the Windale Hub.

In the draft climate resilience plan, the council said the vision was that "the nine lakeside suburbs from Teralba to Toronto will build climate resilience by proactively planning and preparing for, and adapting to, current and emerging climate-related hazards".

The report makes for sobering reading as the impact of global climate change is predicted to create serious challenges for the council and residents in the suburbs of Teralba, Booragul, Marmong Point, Woodrising, Bolton Point, Fennell Bay, Fassifern, Blackalls Park and Toronto.

The council has previously adopted the Marks Point and Belmont South Local Adaptation Plan and the Pelican, Blacksmiths, Swansea, Swansea Heads and Caves Beach Local Adaptation Plan.

These plans identified tidal inundation, sea level rise and storm surges as the biggest risks to ratepayer property and public infrastructure in eastern Lake Macquarie.

However, suburbs between Teralba and Toronto also face the threat of increasingly frequent bushfires due to rises in temperature.

According to the council's report, the T2T area will experience a 45 per cent increase in severe fire weather days by 2030 and a 130 per cent rise by 2090, compared to 1995.

Toronto (533), Blackalls Park (299) and Bolton Point (312) are identified as the suburbs with the most homes on fire-prone land.

Compared to 1995, the extreme rainfall each year is expected to increase by 10 per cent by 2030 and 19.7 per cent by 2050.

Five out of the nine T2T suburbs are tipped to have houses impacted by flooding, with Blackalls Park (110), Toronto (92) and Teralba (29) boasting the most at risk.

Liberal West Ward councillor Jason Pauling urged all residents in the T2T suburbs to read the climate resilience plan and contribute when it's on public exhibition.

"The key bit I'd be highlighting is residents of Teralba, Blackalls Park, and particularly Toronto, are listed highest for exposure to a number of elements like flooding, lake level rise, bushfire, and social and economic [problems]," Cr Pauling said.

The lake water level is expected to rise by 0.4 metres in 2050 from 1990 records and by 0.9m in 2100, causing low-lying areas to be permanently inundated.

Blackalls Park (168), Toronto (144) and Teralba (54) would have the most homes affected by the predicted lake water level rise.

The western side of Lake Macquarie experiences an annual average of 12 extreme heat days when temperatures reach or exceed 35 degrees.

That is projected to increase to 17 days per year by 2030 and 27 days per year by 2090.

At the moment, 9.1 per cent of Lake Macquarie's population of 214,000 residents live in the suburbs between Teralba and Toronto.

However, that is expected to rise with suburbs like Teralba and Fennell Bay identified for residential growth over the next 20 years.

Cr Pauling said he would like to see more detail about how the council can actively prepare for these predicted climate issues.

"Everyone wants a resilient community that thrives, and the key is getting the balance right between restrictive practices, financial impact and appropriate safety and resilience," Cr Pauling said.

title: FED:Farmers get on front foot in evolving war against weeds
bodyText:
Australian grain and cotton growers are proving weeds can be beaten, investing significantly in strategies to help improve their control.
   Managing weeds costs the grain and cotton industries an estimated $4.4 billion per year, a report from Australia's national science agency CSIRO has found.


   Despite the large expenditure, growers are reaping the rewards. The impact of crop yield has fallen from 2.8 million tonnes in 2016 to 1.2 million tonnes in 2025, which translates into higher production and income.
   "Weed control remains one of the biggest annual costs for growers, but the investment is paying off," CSIRO research scientist Rick Llewellyn said.
   "By staying ahead of the weed seed bank, resistance and adopting smarter, more targeted practices, growers are protecting long-term profitability and enabling flexibility in their system."
   Weed management demands being on the front foot and strategic planning, central west NSW fifth-generation farmer Richie Quigley said.
   "We spend a huge amount of time and money combating weeds and there is a lot of strategy behind it to make sure we are using all the tools in the toolbox," he told AAP.
   "They are becoming much harder to kill and control and we have to be at the top of our game to be able to manage them."
   Growers are combining pre-emergent herbicides, harvest weed seed control, crop rotation and new precision spraying technologies in their management strategy.
   Effective weed control was critical in adapting to climate change, CSIRO technical officer Jackie Ouzman said.
   "Climate variability does pose significant challenges to growers but they are responding really positively to these challenges," she said.
   "Growers are well positioned to cope with more variable climate, with the practises they're currently doing."
   The most costly weeds to manage are ryegrass, brome grass, sow thistle, wild radish and wild oats, while the costliest fallow weeds in grain production at a national level are melons, heliotrope and fleabane.
   The CSIRO study shows the need for continued investment in weed management research to unlock productivity, climate resilience and sustainable land use.
   "The only reason we're not seeing widespread yield losses from weeds today is because of years of sustained research and grower innovation," Dr Llewellyn said.
   "This is a quiet success story, but it's a battle where you can't pause - the weed challenge keeps evolving and demanding new solutions."

title: Half of island's residents want to live here
bodyText:
More than half of the citizens of the Pacific nation of Tuvalu have applied for a visa to permanently migrate to Australia.

Just over a month ago, Australia opened the The Falepili Mobility Pathway ballot, a program to provide citizens of the tiny island nation of Tuvalu a permanent migration pathway to Australia.

The country has a population of just 10,643, while at least 5157 of them entered the lottery - more than half of the nation's people.

This was through 1466 registrations, with many of the people being included as family members on applications.

The ballot, which closed on Friday, randomly selected up to 280 people each year to apply for the visa.

It is open to all Tuvalu citizens, regardless of age, and visa holders do not need to gain employment in Australia before applying. If the pace of applications keeps up, it could mean the entire population of Tuvalu could live in Australia within 40 years.

Selections for the ballot will take place between July 25 and January 25 next year.

The scheme allows successful applicants to live, work and study anywhere in Australia indefinitely, sponsor relatives to also migrate to Australia, and apply for citizenship once eligible. The population of the island nation is one of the world's most exposed to the effects of climate change, with this program providing a path to flee as the impacts worsen. The pathway is part of the Australia-Tuvalu Falepili Union that both countries signed on August 28, 2024, part of which is to build climate resilience.

title: July 14, 2025: University of Kansas Cancer Center: Study finds cities with proactive, risk-tolerant governing styles most likely to have ambitious climate strategies
bodyText:
A new study led by two researchers with the School of Public Affairs & Administration at the University of Kansas finds that cities with proactive, learning-oriented and risk-tolerant governance styles are significantly more likely to implement ambitious climate resilience strategies.

The peer-reviewed article in the journal Climate Policy, titled "Do cities with greater transformative governance capacity pursue more ambitious policies? Examining U.S. cities through the lens of climate resiliency," analyzes survey data from 386 U.S. cities and introduces the concept of transformative governance capacity, or TGC, a behavioral framework emphasizing learning, proactivity and risk acceptance as key drivers of innovative local climate action.

The findings show that cities with higher TGC are significantly more likely to participate in the Federal Emergency Management Agency's Community Rating System, a voluntary program that incentivizes advanced flood risk mitigation beyond federal minimums. These cities not only join the program at higher rates but also achieve higher CRS scores - an indication that they implement more ambitious policies, defined in the study as efforts that exceed baseline regulatory requirements and proactively address long-term risks. This suggests that TGC is a strong predictor of local policy ambition.

title: Housing resilience is 'a priority'
bodyText:
The federal government needs to take the lead in making housing more resilient as more homes face extreme weather due to climate change, the Productivity Commission argues.

Without action, the cost of this risk will balloon from $9bn a year to $35bn a year by 2050, its interim report on the transition to net zero emissions by 2050 reads.

"Failure to act will be a drain on productivity growth," the Productivity Commission has warned.

"Without adaptation, labour productivity losses due to increased workplace exposure to heat from a 3-4 degree increase in global temperatures are estimated to reduce economic output by between $135bn and $423bn cumulatively between 2023 and 2063 (2022-23 dollars).

"Australia's productivity growth may also suffer from the higher costs of responding to and recovering from disasters - adapting ahead of time can reduce impacts and save costs in the long run, freeing up resources for more productive activities." This would mean that beyond climate risks and mitigation being factored into new builds under the National Construction Code, -existing homes would have to be retrofitted with upgrades, the Productivity Commission states.

As such, the government should look for mechanisms to provide incentives in this direction, it adds.

"To build the resilience of the existing stock, government could identify mechanisms to: increase finance for retrofitting homes, such as by subsidising resilience upgrades for vulnerable households in high-risk areas; â€¦ support households to build back to a higher standard of resilience after a natural disaster; â€¦ improve the resilience of social housing, such as by committing to meet minimum resilience ratings; addressing barriers to landlord investment, such as by implementing minimum standards for rental housing in high-risk areas," the report reads.

The commission admits resilience rating requirements on rental homes will "impose significant compliance costs" and that any carrot-and-stick measures in the regulatory environment must pass a cost-benefit analysis.

The commission also suggests an expanded climate risk information database, a star-rating system of homes' climate resilience, a cross-jurisdictional agreement to take steps to improve housing resilience, and expanded responsibility for the Climate Change Authority to monitor and evaluate progress on housing resilience. The star-rating system "should be outcome-based, with ratings reflecting potential damages from climate hazards", the commission argues. "Ratings should account for location-specific climate hazards and the characteristics of a property."

title: Tas interests at their core
bodyText:
While the final outcome of the 2025 Tasmanian State Election remains uncertain, another crucial political milestone occurred yesterday with the swearing-in of Tasmania's representatives in federal parliament. Among them, experienced Labor MP Julie Collins continues her service for Franklin, joined by three fresh but familiar faces - Rebecca White for Lyons, Jess Teesdale for Bass, and Anne Urquhart, who transitions from the Senate to represent Braddon. Independent Andrew Wilkie also returns to Canberra after being re-elected in Clark.

Together, this team carries the responsibility of speaking for Tasmania in a national forum that too often overlooks the unique needs of our island state. Their voices are vital - not just in debating legislation, but in shaping policy and funding decisions that can profoundly impact the lives of everyday Tasmanians.

From securing health and education funding, to championing regional infrastructure, housing solutions, and climate resilience, Tasmania's federal MPs must work to ensure our priorities are not lost in the noise of bigger mainland electorates. The balance of experience and renewal in this new federal cohort is promising. Collins's ministerial background brings weight, while White and Teesdale arrive with state-level leadership credentials and a deep understanding of their communities. Urquhart brings longstanding union ties and advocacy experience, now applied with a more targeted electorate lens. They must work collaboratively, regardless of political stripe, to get results, because Tasmania cannot afford to be a political afterthought. We face pressing challenges, from rising cost-of-living pressures to growing demands on health and aged care services, and the impacts of a changing climate on agriculture and coastal communities. Strong, united federal representation is a necessity, not a luxury.

On June 9-13, some of the world's top leaders in marine science and protection convened in Nice, France for the third United Nations Ocean Conference (UNOC). University of California, Santa Cruz and the Center for Coastal Climate Resilience (CCCR) had strong representation at UNOC and the opening Blue Economy Finance Forum (BEFF) in Monaco, with several fellows and faculty attending to share highlights from their research and engage in global dialogues about climate adaptation, mitigation and the future of our coasts.

The rise of social media in recent decades has brought with it a steady drumbeat of warnings from experts around the world. The unchecked spread of disinformation, propaganda, and hate speech on these platforms can fuel the darkest of human impulses. New research led by politics and legal studies double-major John Bentley shows how the roll-out of social media in developing countries could actually increase the risk of genocide.

Source: Company Website

As the science community's focus on climate change and adaptation continues to grow, research fellows are playing a pivotal role in driving the innovation needed to build greater resilience in the face of climate change. The University of California, Santa Cruz Center for Coastal Climate Resilience has made a major commitment in the past 2.5 years to support and bring to campus more than 60 Fellows at all levels from early career grad students to senior fellows. Fellows cover programs across campus and include business leaders, indigenous diplomats, graduate students in Coastal Science & Policy and Science Communications programs, and an artist in residence, among others. In a series of perspective pieces we will tell some of the stories of how their work drives innovation locally, nationally, and globally.

Grey Bears Development Manager Kayla Traber provides insight into the legacy of Mailliard and the continued impact Grey Bears has on the Santa Cruz senior population. + HKUST CHEMISTS DISCOVER A "SUPER" PHOTOREDUCTANT TO LEAP FORWARD IN PHOTOCATALYSIS

Chemists at the School of Science of the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (HKUST) have recently made a significant breakthrough in photocatalysis by unveiling a "super" photoreductant, marking a major advancement in organic synthesis.

Quantum dots (QDs) hold great promise as photocatalysts for promoting photoredox chemistry, however, their application in photocatalytic organic transformations has lagged behind that of small molecule photosensitizers due to the limited understanding of their photophysics. While various studies have explored the generation of hot electrons from QDs as a strategy to enhance photoreduction efficiencies, achieving effective hot-electron generation under mild conditions has posed a significant challenge.

title: August 06, 2025: University of Hawai i Sets New Funding Benchmark Amid Federal Uncertainty
bodyText:
The University of Hawaiʻi has achieved a remarkable milestone by securing extramural funding totaling $734 million for fiscal year 2025, marking the fourth consecutive year the institution has surpassed the half-billion dollar threshold. This announcement was made on 6th June 2025 and represents a significant increase of $118.3 million, or 19.2%, over the previous record of $615.7 million set in fiscal year 2024. The funding, which comes from various external agencies including the federal government, industry, and nonprofit organizations, supports essential research and training initiatives conducted by the University of Hawaiʻi's faculty and staff.

UH President Wendy Hensel emphasized the importance of this achievement in a time of growing concerns regarding federal research support. "This year marks another record-breaking milestone in federal support for the University of Hawaiʻi, highlighting the excellence of our researchers and our university system," Hensel stated. However, the backdrop of this success is troubling, as 66 grants worth over $89 million have been terminated due to shifting federal priorities. The anticipated cuts in federal budgets affecting major research funding bodies like the National Science Foundation and the National Institutes of Health add to the complexities of securing future funding.

The University of Hawaiʻi Manoa, the flagship campus of the UH system, led the way with $570.4 million in extramural awards. The UH System as a whole brought in $98.7 million, while UH Community Colleges, UH Hilo, and UH West Oʻahu contributed $31.3 million, $23.9 million, and $9.7 million, respectively. Interim Provost Vassilis L. Syrmos commended the UH Manoa research community for their significant contributions, noting that their dedication drives the university's research enterprise, which is vital for the well-being of both the state and the wider world.

An economic impact report from the University of Hawaiʻi Economic Research Organization indicated that research-related expenditures at UH reached $476.8 million in fiscal year 2020, contributing significantly to the state economy. This year's record in extramural funding reflects the university's ongoing commitment to addressing critical issues such as health disparities and climate resilience. Governor Josh Green emphasized the importance of UH as a key driver of innovation and economic resilience in Hawaiʻi. He stated, "This record-breaking year of research funding underscores UH's essential role in tackling our most pressing challenges."

Despite the positive funding news, stakeholders remain cautious about the future funding landscape. U.S. Senator Brian Schatz and other congressional representatives highlighted the need for continued support for the University of Hawaiʻi in light of potential federal funding cuts. As the institution celebrates its record achievement, the focus will be on navigating the challenges ahead to maintain the momentum of its research initiatives, ensuring that the university continues to play a pivotal role in the advancement of both local and global communities.

title: Take us to a stable future
bodyText:
Just 14 months after the last state election, we are on track to return to the same parliamentary deadlock, and the same political uncertainty.

This cycle is not sustainable.

Democracy, at its best, delivers representation that reflects the will of the people. But it must also deliver function. Government exists to govern - not just to campaign, bicker, or stall.

Without a majority or a mature willingness to collaborate across party lines, the parliament risks becoming a chamber of gridlock rather than progress.

In that environment, stability becomes the first casualty, and the people of Tasmania are the ones who suffer most.

We cannot afford to keep rehashing the same election every year or so because leaders can't find common ground.

Polling conducted by EMRS on behalf of the Liberal Party shows the 2025 election likely returning a parliament similar to the one it voted in just 14 months ago.

If a minority government is again the likely result, then Tasmanians deserve firm assurances from those seeking to lead. Will they work constructively with the Greens and independents? Will they respect the mandates of crossbenchers elected by significant portions of the public?

Or will we again be dragged through another year of brinkmanship, instability and ultimately another early election?

The state faces real, pressing challenges - housing, health, cost of living, climate resilience - and those challenges won't wait for political egos to resolve themselves.

The public has done its job by turning out to vote tomorrow and in record early numbers.

Now it's time for elected representatives to do theirs. Work together, govern responsibly, and give Tasmania the stability it desperately needs.

Otherwise, we're doomed to keep circling the electoral roundabout. It's expensive, exhausting and utterly unproductive.

title: All creatures great and expired
bodyText:
These birds can sound the alarm for our greatest threats.

An amazing new building containing literally millions of dead animals is to be officially opened in Canberra.

The Diversity building on the CSIRO campus cost $90 million and houses 13 million specimens of plants and animals.

They include 55,000 birds, 17,000 orchids, 2.4 million moths and butterflies and more than 7 million beetles - all making up a comprehensive picture for scientists to monitor how the Australian environment morphs over time and over the vast distances of our country continent.

Some of the specimens were collected 150 years ago and some of them were shot in the cause of science more recently. Either way, they now find themselves in the temperature-controlled vaults that are bushfire and pest-resistant in the shadow of Black Mountain in Canberra.

The specimens come from all over Australia and some were gathered more than a century ago. They vary in time and place so they can be compared.

This means that the scientists can track how species change over time and over distance.

And that means that if a new invasive species appears, for example, the CSIRO researchers can tell if it has been in Australia before. If it hasn't - if there isn't a specimen like it in the collection - the alarm bells start to ring.

"We have pests that are coming at our borders all the time and threatening our biosecurity , threatening our food safety, threatening our health, and it's often hard to know which of those species are new and which ones have been here for a really long time," Erin Hahn, conservation geneticist at the complex, said.

Two existing collections are now brought together in the building in Canberra, which neighbours the National Herbarium and the Australian National Tree Centre.

They form part of what is known as the National Research Collections Australia. The big CSIRO hub is in Canberra but the Australian National Algae Culture Collection and the Australian National Fish Collection are both in Hobart, and the Australian Tropical Herbarium is in Cairns.

In the Diversity building in Canberra, Dr Hahn stood next to trays and trays of dead galahs.

"These are species that you might see around Canberra, and they're just one of the many, many species that we have here in Australia which is one of the most biodiverse places on Earth," she said. "Each of these specimens is a precious record of the biodiversity that we have in a given area. One individual will tell you roughly what that species looks like, but having an array of them will tell you that diversity within a species."

The building was jointly funded by CSIRO and the federal government.

CSIRO's chief executive, Doug Hilton, said the facility would help monitor the environment, pests and weeds. It would help protect endangered species, prevent disease, and harness nature sustainably.

"For more than a century, our collections have quietly underpinned Australian science, policy, agriculture, biosecurity, and biodiversity conservation," Dr Hilton said. "This work contributes directly to the national interest. It informs biosecurity actions, climate resilience strategies, and land management activities."

+ CANVA [10 Press Releases]

+ 5 LESSONS FOR GOVERNMENT TEAMS FROM THE CANVA PLAYBOOK

As communication channels evolve and public expectations rise, government agencies are rethinking how they connect with their communities. It's no longer just about showing up in times of crisis - proactive outreach is becoming essential. By getting ahead of the conversation, agencies can build trust, strengthen relationships, and drive meaningful engagement.

Drawing on our playbook for Canva for Government, we've pulled together five key lessons. These insights can help you strengthen your messaging, build stronger community connections, and keep citizens informed and engaged.

Whether you're responding to a public health emergency or improving everyday engagement, these tips can help you create more meaningful conversations with the people you serve.

Source: Company Website

+ CANVA NAMED ON CNBC'S 2025 DISRUPTOR 50 LIST

We're proud to share that Canva has been named the #5 company on CNBC's 2025 Disruptor 50 list - a recognition of private companies transforming industries and reshaping the future of work.

Since launching in 2013, our mission has been to empower the world to design. From individuals and small businesses to global enterprises, we've built a platform that unlocks creativity and collaboration for everyone, no matter their design experience.

This recognition reflects our continued growth and innovation, including new AI-powered tools, innovative workplace solutions, and the expansion of our global team.

Source: Company Website

+ CANVA REPORT: WHY DATA STORYTELLING IS THE SKILL EVERY TEAM NEEDS NOW

When I was a climate journalist, I spent hours staring at numbers, trying to wrangle raw data into something people could actually understand, let alone care about. That challenge stuck with me. Years later, it became the spark for founding Flourish: a platform to help anyone - not just data experts - make sense of complexity through clear, visual storytelling.

That need is now greater than ever.

In a world increasingly driven by data, teams are expected to make faster, smarter decisions - backed by insights, not instinct. But what happens when data feels out of reach, buried in spreadsheets, or too complex to communicate?

Our global study, Beyond the Numbers: How Data Storytelling Redefines Communication, reveals a growing confidence gap between data's potential and professionals'. Based on insights from more than 2,400 marketing and sales professionals across eight countries - including the United States, United Kingdom, France, Germany, Spain, Australia, India, and Japan - the research highlights a critical opportunity: empowering teams with intuitive tools and the skills to tell meaningful stories with data.

Source: Company Website

+ AI IN ACTION: PRACTICAL STRATEGIES FROM CANVA AND HUBSPOT TEAMS

AI is transforming how teams work - but it's not just about speed. In this webinar recap, leaders from Canva, HubSpot and more share how they're using AI to rethink marketing and customer experience. From real-world wins to common roadblocks, here's what they've learned so far.

AI is already reshaping how business teams work - and in marketing and customer success, the shift goes beyond efficiency. It's about moving faster, connecting more meaningfully, and staying focused on what matters most.

In a recent webinar co-hosted by Canva and HubSpot, leaders from both companies shared how their teams are putting AI into action, the results they're seeing, and the lessons learned along the way.

Source: Company Website

+ CANVA CELEBRATING 10 MILLION TREES PLANTED THROUGH ONE PRINT, ONE TREE

When we launched Canva Print, we wanted every order to make a positive impact. Through our One Print, One Tree initiative, we've now planted over 10 million trees - restoring landscapes, supporting communities, and helping build climate resilience around the world.

When we launched Canva Print in 2021, we knew it would have a footprint. However, we also saw an opportunity: what if we could help restore the planet with every Print order?

That idea became One Print, One Tree: our commitment to plant a tree for every Canva Print order. What began as a simple promise has since grown into a global reforestation program - focused not just on planting trees, but on restoring landscapes, supporting communities, conserving habitats for wildlife, and contributing to long-term climate resilience.

Source: Company Website

+ WHAT'S NEW IN CANVA EDUCATION: BUILT WITH TEACHERS, FOR TEACHERS

We truly believe every teacher deserves tools that are powerful, intuitive, and built for the real challenges of the classroom. At Canva Create 2025, we introduced a powerful new set of features built to support every teacher and engage every learner - whether you're planning lessons, personalizing learning, or finding new ways to bring content to life.

Inspired by real feedback from our educator community, these tools help make teaching more creative, engaging, and efficient - all in one easy-to-use platform. From AI-powered planning to interactive content and smarter insights, these updates are here to help you spend less time on admin, and more time doing what you do best: teaching.

Source: Company Website

+ CANVA JOURNALISM IN THE VISUAL AGE: A FRONT ROW SEAT TO THE FUTURE OF STORYTELLING

Journalism is evolving - fast. Deadlines are tighter, platforms are multiplying, and expectations are rising. But one thing hasn't changed: the power of a well-told story.

Last week in New York City, we brought together more than 150 journalists, editors, and media professionals for Journalism in the Visual Age - our first-ever community-led event designed specifically for the journalism and media community. Centered on one core idea, the event aimed to give working journalists real tools, timely inspiration, and fresh ideas to support their craft in today's visual-first world.

Here are the top takeaways.

Source: Company Website

+ CELEBRATING EXTRAORDINARY EDUCATORS: CANVA AND CBS HONOR 5 TEACHERS MAKING A DIFFERENCE

Since the beginning, we've been on a mission to empower the world to design meaningful change - in classrooms, workplaces, and communities everywhere. As part of that mission, Canva Education is available 100% free for teachers and students, helping millions bring creativity into learning every day.

Now, we're proud to team up with CBS and journalist David Begnaud to spotlight five extraordinary educators whose impact reaches well beyond their schools. Here's everything you need to know about this heartwarming moment.

Shining a light on unsung heroes Designed to celebrate the everyday heroes whose stories often go untold, our latest partnership with CBS is our way of saying thank you to the educators who guide, uplift, and ignite a lifelong love of learning.

Source: Company Website

+ WHAT'S NEW FOR CANVA IN JAPAN

From bold brand moments to community connections, Canva's momentum in Japan keeps growing. With a deep focus on local creativity and collaboration, we're proud to see our platform empowering more individuals, educators, and businesses across the country.

At Canva, we believe everyone should feel empowered to bring their ideas to life - and it's been incredible to see millions of people around the world unlocking their creativity and achieving their goals with Canva, wherever they may be. Japan is no exception.

We've doubled our growth in Japan over the past year, a true testament to the increasing demand for accessible, intuitive visual communication tools. With over 170 million designs created on Canva, Japan continues to be one of our fastest-growing markets globally. To keep up with this amazing momentum, we opened our new office in Shibuya - the epicenter of Tokyo's creative scene - now home to our growing team.

Source: Company Website

+ FROM CANVA TO CAMPAIGN: CREATING LINKEDIN ADS JUST GOT EASIER

The new LinkedIn Ads app for Canva is here, giving marketers a more seamless way to create and publish ad campaigns. This integration lets teams design video and image ads in Canva and export them directly to LinkedIn Campaign Manager - streamlining the path from concept to campaign.

In today's fast-moving marketing world, teams are under pressure to deliver more content - faster and without sacrificing quality. As strategies shift and channels grow, the need for high-impact creative that's easy to produce and scale has never been clearer.

That's where the new LinkedIn Ads app for Canva comes in.

Available now to our entire Canva community, the app is designed to streamline how marketing teams create and publish LinkedIn ad campaigns, connecting Canva's visual communication platform directly with LinkedIn Campaign Manager. From first draft to final asset, it's now easier than ever to move from idea to impact.

+ KIIT UNIVERSITY: KINS CELEBRATES WORLD BREASTFEEDING WEEK

+ GREED IS THE ROOT OF DECLINING SOCIAL VALUES, WARNS JUSTICE SANTOSH HEGDE SPEAKING AT KIIT LAW SCHOOL

Greed is a disease for which there is no medicine, and it is at the root of the fall in our social values, said former judge of Supreme Court and retired Karnataka Lokayukta Justice N Santosh Hegde. In a powerful and candid address at KIIT Law School on "Fall in Social Values and Its Consequences", Justice Hegde lamented how the relentless pursuit of money and power has eroded moral integrity and weakened society's foundations.

Source: Company Website

+ KIIT UNIVERSITYKSOM HOSTS 16TH NATIONAL HR CONCLAVE

KIIT School of Management (KSOM) hosted its 16th National HR Conclave on August 9, 2025, themed "Navigating the Hybrid Future: Agile, Adaptive, and Integrated Workplaces." The conclave highlighted the strategies for building flexible, resilient, and human-centric organizations in a hybrid era. Dr. Achyuta Samanta, Founder, KIIT, KISS & KIMS graced the occasion and interacted with the corporate dignitaries.

Delivering the keynote address at the conclave, Mr. Sarthak Behuria, Chairman & Chairperson of the Board of Directors, Reliance BP Mobility Ltd. noted that the traditional 9-to-5 is giving way to a new era of work defined by agility, adaptability, and empathy. Drawing from his vast experience, he shared a few real-life instances that illustrated these values in action. His speech was deeply humane and personal, reflecting the importance of trust and connection in today's workplace.

Prof. Saranjit Singh, Vice Chancellor, KIIT Deemed to be University, highlighted that the theme of hybrid workplaces and the hybrid future can be captured in three words: agile, adaptive, and integrated. Drawing parallels between industry and academia, he noted that education has also been disrupted by market changes, making agility and adaptability essential for institutions to thrive. He spoke about the growing influence of artificial intelligence and the need to adapt to its impact on education and work.

Source: Company Website

+ KIIT UNIVERSITY KINS FACULTY INVITED AS A SPEAKER FOR FDP

Prof Asokan R, HOD of Medical Surgical Nursing and Incharge of R&D at KINS, was invited as a distinguished speaker for the Faculty Development Programme organized by the GITAM Institute of Nursing, GITAM Deemed to be University, Visakhapatnam. This event was held on 30th July 2025 and attended by various nursing specialists.

The speaker delivered an insightful session on the topic "Professional Development and Accountability" highlighting the evolving roles of nursing faculty in the academic and clinical domains. The session focused on the importance of continuous professional growth, ethical responsibilities, and maintaining accountability in nursing practice. Real world examples and current trends in nursing education were integrated into the presentation making it engaging and thought provoking for the participants.

Source: Company Website

+ KIIT UNIVERSITY: EMPOWERING HANDS FOR LITTLE LIVES: KIMS SCHOOL OF PHYSIOTHERAPY HOSTS ADVANCED WORKSHOP ON PAEDIATRIC FUNCTIONAL THERAPY MODULE- II

August 22 2024: IAG releases Climate Action Plan

The Climate Action Plan includes IAG's updated FY30 emissions reduction interim targets and outlines how IAG is supporting the transition towards a low-carbon, climate resilient economy.

IAG Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer, Nick Hawkins said, "The need to act on climate change has never been more urgent and we're proud to play our part. Our Climate Action Plan demonstrates our commitment to helping customers and communities in Australia and New Zealand adapt to a changing climate and transition to a net zero future."

With the goal to become a net zero insurer by 2050, IAG is working to achieve net zero emissions across its operations, while actively strengthening climate resilience and capturing opportunities through the transition.

IAG's Climate Action Plan is focused on three key action areas:

1. Adapting its direct operations

IAG is focused on lowering scope 1 and 2 emissions to meet a science aligned 1.5C pathway and transitioning its direct operations to build climate resilience.

2. Supporting its value chain

Recognising that its influence extends beyond its immediate operations, IAG is using its knowledge and reach to help accelerate the transition to net zero across its full value chain, supporting customers, suppliers and partners.

3. Collaborating and advocating

Driving systemic change through its partnerships and advocacy work, IAG is supporting communities to build climate resilience and is sharing its understanding of climate risks and opportunities by partnering with governments, industry, and other organisations.

As detailed in the Climate Action Plan, IAG has updated its emissions reduction interim targets to net zero scope 1 and 2 emissions by FY30 from a FY24 baseline and it will also reduce limited upstream operational scope 3 emissions by 50% from a FY24 baseline.

Press Release article 4 of 4, Source: Company Website, 311 words

August 21 2024: IAG FY24 Results

Results overview IAG today announced its 2024 full-year results, reporting a net profit after tax (NPAT) of $898m, up 7.9% on FY23. This increase was driven by an 11% rise in net earned premiums, an improvement in the insurance profit, and higher investment income on shareholder funds of $286m up 35% on the previous year.

The insurance profit of $1,438m was up 79.1% on FY23 and equated to a reported margin of 15.6% (FY23: 9.6%). The company's natural perils costs of $983m, $115m below the $1098m allowance, positively impacted the insurance profit.

The IAG Board declared a final dividend of 17.0cps (FY23: 9cps) bringing the full year dividend to 27cps (FY23: 15cps).

Commenting on the company's performance, IAG Managing Director and CEO Nick Hawkins said:

"Today's result reflects the strength of the IAG business as well as the operational improvements we have implemented. The trust our customers have in our brands is reflected in continued high customer advocacy and retention in our retail businesses in Australia and New Zealand. We are well positioned to continue supporting our customers and the broader economy.

"The strategic measures we have put in place over the past few years have created a stronger and more resilient IAG. We've streamlined our Australian business, established a clear brand strategy and launched NRMA Insurance nationally, outside of Victoria. We have also improved our claims management capability to ensure we are well placed to support our customers when they need us the most.

"We've delivered on our target of at least $250m in insurance profit from our Intermediated Insurance Australia business, and significantly improved our technology platform that delivers the products and services we provide to our retail customers.

"New Zealand saw a material uplift in our pricing capability and risk management as we migrated policies to the Enterprise Platform.

Activities

Tetra Tech, Inc. is a leading global provider of consulting and engineering services, headquartered in Pasadena, California. The company primarily generates its revenue from two core segments: Government Services Group (GSG) and Commercial/International Services Group (CIG). The GSG, which accounts for the largest portion of revenue, focuses on providing technical services to U.S. federal, state, and local government agencies, including water resource management, environmental restoration, and infrastructure support. The CIG segment serves commercial clients and international markets with similar expertise in water, environment, and energy solutions. Among its fastest-growing areas, Tetra Tech has seen significant expansion in renewable energy projects, particularly in wind and solar infrastructure, as well as climate resilience and disaster recovery services, driven by increasing global demand for sustainable solutions. With a strong commitment to innovation, Tetra Tech continues to address complex challenges in water, environment, and infrastructure for a diverse client base worldwide. It is the NASDAQ's 5th largest Consumer product/services company by market capitalisation.
